citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection there were several kittens that were displaying signs of illness that were either due, or past due,
on their FVRCP vaccinations, and had yet to be seen by a veterinarian. The symptoms for the following kittens ranged
from yellowish-brown crust built up on nostrils, clear nasal discharge, frequent sneezing, and/or watery eyes: 6 Bengal
kittens (that had yet to be microchipped) housed in the white cage near the window in the living room; 4 Bengal kittens
(Microchip #’s: 985141005790884, 985141005790195, 985141005791045, and 985141005790573) in the white cage
near the kitchen in the living room; 3 Bengal kittens (Microchip #’s: 985141005790456, 985141005790202, and
985141005794887) housed in a tall black cage near the kitchen, immediately adjacent to the white cage; and 3 Bengal
kittens (Microchip #’s: 985141005790417, 985141005794471, and 985141005790930) housed in a tall black cage in the
living room near the back hallway. There was a Leopard cat kitten (not microchipped) - housed in the second room to the
left off the hallway- that had active diarrhea (liquid consistency dripped along sides of water bowl and semi-solid clumps
adjacent to the water bowl inside of its litterbox), lethargy, shallow breathing, and cloudy eyes with squinting and clear
discharge from both. The latter kitten was being treated by the licensee after it stopped eating the week before (started
eating again this week), but like the other kittens, had yet to be examined by a veterinarian. Failure to follow appropriate
methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases can negatively impact the overall health and well-being of the
animals, and could possibly lead to avoidable suffering and death. Each dealer must establish and maintain programs of
adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases
and injuries. All kittens must be examined and treated by a veterinarian by the end of the day.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Gervais Edmonds-Wiggins, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
At the time of inspection there were several kittens that were displaying signs of illness that were either due, or past due, 
on their FVRCP vaccinations, and had yet to be seen by a veterinarian. The symptoms for the following kittens ranged 
from yellowish-brown crust built up on nostrils, clear nasal discharge, frequent sneezing, and/or watery eyes: 6 Bengal 
kittens (that had yet to be microchipped) housed in the white cage near the window in the living room; 4 Bengal kittens 
(Microchip #’s: 985141005790884, 985141005790195, 985141005791045, and 985141005790573) in the white cage 
near the kitchen in the living room; 3 Bengal kittens (Microchip #’s: 985141005790456, 985141005790202, and 
985141005794887) housed in a tall black cage near the kitchen, immediately adjacent to the white cage; and 3 Bengal 
kittens (Microchip #’s: 985141005790417, 985141005794471, and 985141005790930) housed in a tall black cage in the 
living room near the back hallway. There was a Leopard cat kitten (not microchipped) - housed in the second room to the 
left off the hallway- that had active diarrhea (liquid consistency dripped along sides of water bowl and semi-solid clumps 
adjacent to the water bowl inside of its litterbox), lethargy, shallow breathing, and cloudy eyes with squinting and clear 
discharge from both. The latter kitten was being treated by the licensee after it stopped eating the week before (started 
eating again this week), but like the other kittens, had yet to be examined by a veterinarian. Failure to follow appropriate 
methods to prevent, control, diagnose and treat diseases can negatively impact the overall health and well-being of the 
animals, and could possibly lead to avoidable suffering and death. Each dealer must establish and maintain programs of 
adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases 
and injuries. All kittens must be examined and treated by a veterinarian by the end of the day. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Gervais Edmonds-Wiggins, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
